Andy, I'd say this is a about right.  I elaborate a bit below each 
part of=
 your question:

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "afcarl2" <a.carl@...> wrote:=

>
> Jason or Ken,
> 
>    I am attempting to understand the nature of inpu=
ts & outputs as 
> applied to both the Hypercube and substrate networks, wi=
thout being 
> limited to the geometric nature of the visual-based examples=
. The 
> examples provided were helpful, but I am striving for a more 
gene=
ral 
> guideline for application to more general problems.
> 
>    Would it=
 be correct to say that:
> 
> (a) Substrate Network: Inputs & Outputs ident=
ified as typical to 
> application of conventional NEAT to a problem of int=
erest;
> 

This statement is correct although you might do things that you =
would 
avoid doing in conventional NEAT because HyperNEAT can deal with so =

many more inputs and outputs.  So you might for example output a high 
res=
olution representation of your possible decisions, which is 
something you =
normally wouldn't do in regular NEAT.

> (b) Hypercube Network: (i) Inputs:=
 Other descriptors/parameters 
(i.e. 
> geometric coordinates being a subse=
t thereof), associated with a 
given 
> substrate network node (i.e. like a=
 timestamp associated with a 
> coordinate point comprising a trajectory), =
mutually exclusive of 
the 
> descriptor/parameter expressly identified in =
the substrate node, 
each 
> being collected together and collectively iden=
tified as either 
a "from" 
> or "to" terminator of a link between any two =
substrate nodes; and 
(ii) 
> Output: Weight of link between the currently =
identified "from" 
and "to" 
> substrate nodes.
> 

I think this characteri=
zes it well, although there is even more 
flexibility.  You can for example=
 use additional outputs on the CPPN 
to represent additional attributes of =
links and/or nodes.  

The timestamp idea is interesting- if I understand c=
orrectly it would 
cause the network to change over time in a deterministic=
 way.  
Although maybe I'm misunderstanding.  But certainly things like tha=
t 
are possible.  

It's difficult to write an accurate general description=
 of exactly 
what goes in and comes out of the CPPN at this point because I=
 have 
no doubt that at this early stage that new ideas are going to broade=
n 
the possibilities beyond what I am currently aware of.   But what you 
s=
aid captures it pretty well for now.

ken
